text.p: These are the leading stories in the Beirut press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
AN-NAHAR
-French President Chirac brings up Lebanon in his talks with Syrian President Assad.
-Prime Minister Hariri says the consultative committee of nations to help finance postwar rebuilding in Lebanon will meet on December 16 in Washington.
-Hizbollah chief Nasrallah says: "The country is on the edge of a volcano and what is needed is an emergency plan to stop the deterioration".
-Hizbollah says the five-nation ceasefire agreement monitoring committee has failed in its mandate.
-Five guerrilla attacks on targets of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army (SLA) militia.
-Transportation Minister Miskawi says that the northern Tripoli port will have a role in the regional economy.
AS-SAFIR
-Lebanon gets $20 million loan from Kuwaiti Development Fund for coastal highway in Beirut.
-Lebanese treasury bill subscriptions reach 15,637 billion Lebanese pounds by October 10.
-Speaker of the outgoing parliament Nabih Berri to be re-elected on Tuesday by a majority of MPs' votes to head the new national assembly.
-German parliamentary delegation in Beirut.
-Maronite Patriarch Sfeir urges authorities to investigate the alleged financial scandals in public institutions.
AL-ANWAR
-The unofficial consultations by President Hrawi over the formation of the new cabinet begin this week.
AD-DIYAR
-President Assad tells Chirac: "Lebanon is out of its calamity and what hurts it hurts Syria".
NIDA'A AL-WATAN
-Hariri says U.S. President Bill Clinton promised him to reconsider the U.S. travel ban on Lebanon.
